Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Providing an Adaptive Learning Environment for the Acquisition of High Value Manufacturing Skills

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is developing an adaptive learning environment for a wide range of students to attain skills necessary to work in high value manufacturing (HVM) aimed at the energy industry. Houston Community College's (HCC) Petroleum and Manufacturing Engineering Technology programs and Texas A&M University's Department of Engineering Technology and Industrial Distribution are working to create a sustainable certificate program in HVM that provides multiple pathways for community college students while meeting the critical workforce needs of a vital industry.

Innovative pedagogical methods, such as i) competency-based learning and ii) skills needs assessment and provision through online learning modules, allow students an adaptive and personalized education. By incorporating the new Engineering Academy paradigm, as opposed to traditional articulation agreements, this project provides a novel pathway for community college students to transition to a four-year degree program. It also incorporates a new method for trying to ensure that HCC students who matriculate to TAMU receive reverse transfer credit for their associate degrees at HCC. HVM modules are being developed for high school students that are aligned with the Next Generation Science Standards as part of a summer program for teachers. HCC is an open-access institution where over 70% of the students belong to under-represented minority groups and over half of students receive Pell grants. Offering the HVM certificate program at HCC allows underrepresented students a pathway to these high demand STEM careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Collaborative Research- Providing an Adaptive Learning Environment for the Acquisition of High Value Manufacturing Skills (Grant # : DUE 15011952)

Outcomes Report

Overview

This project has developed an adaptive learning environment for a wide range of students with the skills necessary to work in high value manufacturing (HVM) aimed at the energy industry. In collaboration with Houston Community College?s (HCC) Petroleum and Manufacturing Engineering Technology programs, the PIs from Texas A&M University?s Department of Engineering Technology and Industrial Distribution worked with HCC PIs to create a sustainable certificate program in HVM that provides multiple pathways for community college students while meeting the critical workforce needs of a vital industry. In addition, the project has offered summer research and enrichment experience in engineering (E3) to eleven secondary school teachers from multiple school districts in Texas on high value manufacturing. The project also offered four continuing education sessions to professionals from oil and gas industry in the topics related to high value  manufacturing. The participants from both programs (continuing education for industry professionals and the summer enrichment experience for teachers) found the programs to be relevant and well organized.

Intellectual Merit: The proposed project filled a significant gap in the credit and non-credit offerings of community and technical colleges in Texas by offering the unique set skills required for technicians to effectively engage in HVM. The certificate program curriculum provides authentic experiential learning opportunities to meet the needs of industry for technician-level professionals who can contribute immediately. By incorporating the new Engineering Academy paradigm, as opposed to traditional articulation agreements, this project provides a novel pathway for community college students to transition to a four-year degree program. Some of the program?s developed courses use self-paced competency-based aspects to provide a flexible and adaptive learning environment to students.

Broader Impact: Texas ranks first in the nation with respect to manufacturing exports and manufacturing capital investment, and second in manufacturing employment. A significant portion of this HVM activity is related to oil and gas; Texas produces over a third of US crude oil. Through the certificate and continuing education programs, this project has provided an entry point (for new) and re-training opportunity (for current workforce) for a wide array of students into this critical and growing industry. HCC is an open-access institution with over 70% of the students belonging to groups historically under-represented in STEM and over half of their students receiving Pell grants. In the Division of Science and Engineering Technologies, under-represented minorities account for over 65% of the student population. Offering the HVM certificate program at HCC  allows a diverse group of students a pathway to these high demand STEM careers. These students will have the option of pursuing an industry career, an associate degree, or transitioning to a four-year program. Lastly, through the E3 program, several high school teachers were provided with a research and curriculum development experience at Texas A&M on HVM related topics. These teachers then went back to their schools and integrated their experiences and their lessons into high school curricula to improve the understanding and awareness of K-12 students about engineering or  manufacturing careers.

Key Project Objectives and Outcome

A. Establishment of a certificate program in high value manufacturing (outcome: Created a brand new program in HVM, currently students are enrolled in multiple courses)

Exhibit 1 shows overall enrollment numbers in all the courses that are part of the HVM certificate program. Below is the link of the certificate program listed on the HCC website.

https://www.hccs.edu/finder/programs/manufacturing-engineering-technology---high-value-manufacturing---certificate-level-2/

 

B. Expansion of high school teacher and student knowledge in the skills required for HVM and jobs related to HVM through Enrichment experience in engineering (E3) (Outcome: Number of teachers trained: 11, 6 of which implemented their curricula)

Exhibit 2 shows sample project activities of the high school teachers, and Exhibit 3 depicts the program assessment results (pre and post E3 program) and their manufacturing self-efficacy.

 

C. Enhancing knowledge of practicing professionals in HVM topic areas (Outcome: 4 continuing education (CE) sessions were offered, 86 participants from energy industry attended)

See Exhibit 4 for participants summary and Exhibit 5  for program assessment.

 

D. Significant Products

  • 9 peer reviewed publications (7 published and two under submission and review)
  • 4 ATE PI conference posters
  • 7 Graduate students (does not include any graduate thesis student).
  • See Exhibit 6 for Publications list.
